articles.headline: On Fringe of Forests, Homes and Fires Meet
articles.snippet: Americans who live on the edge of government lands in the West are living out a dangerous experiment.
articles.abstract: Americans who live on the edge of government lands in the West are living out a dangerous experiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLEVILLE, Calif. — Lori and Don Morris had just started unpacking the boxes this month in their new dream house — four acres, national forest view, wide open land at their doorstep — when a wildfire raced down the stark bluffs over this high-desert town near the Nevada border.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: For G.I.’s in Iraq, a Harrowing Day Facing a Trap
articles.snippet: The soldiers from Comanche Company’s First Platoon faced a network of houses rigged to explode by insurgents.
articles.abstract: The soldiers from Comanche Company’s First Platoon faced a network of houses rigged to explode by insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 25  The enemy was a phantom who never showed his face but transformed a neighborhood into a network of houses rigged to explode.

articles.headline: Private Equity Investors Hint at Cool Down
articles.snippet: After years of supersize private equity deals, investors have begun to push back at several prominent transactions.
articles.abstract: After years of supersize private equity deals, investors have begun to push back at several prominent transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Murdoch’s Dealings in China: It’s Business, and It’s Personal
articles.snippet: Many companies have tried to break into the Chinese market, but few have been as ardent and unrelenting as Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
articles.abstract: Many companies have tried to break into the Chinese market, but few have been as ardent and unrelenting as Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, June 25 — Many big companies have sought to break into the Chinese market over the past two decades, but few of them have been as ardent and unrelenting as Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.

articles.headline: Billionaire Thinks in Trillions for His Computer Designs
articles.snippet: A co-founder of Sun Microsystems plans to introduce a supercomputer that will compete for the title as world’s fastest.
articles.abstract: A co-founder of Sun Microsystems plans to introduce a supercomputer that will compete for the title as world’s fastest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student and a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Andreas Bechtolsheim designed a simple but powerful personal computer workstation that would help define the modern technology era.

articles.headline: New Scrutiny as Immigrants Die in Custody
articles.snippet: Getting details about immigrants who have died in administrative custody is a difficult undertaking.
articles.abstract: Getting details about immigrants who have died in administrative custody is a difficult undertaking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandra M. Kenley was returning home from her native Barbados in 2005 when she was swept into the United States’ fastest-growing form of incarceration, immigration detention.

articles.headline: No Takeoff, but 2 Visits by the Police
articles.snippet: First the air-conditioning didn’t work. Then the flight was delayed. Finally, a passenger with a video camera began asking some tough questions.
articles.abstract: First the air-conditioning didn’t work. Then the flight was delayed. Finally, a passenger with a video camera began asking some tough questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly four hours last Thursday night, Flight 5637, a 50-seat regional jet, was stuck on the ground by bad weather at Kennedy International Airport. The air-conditioning wasn’t working, and no one seemed to have a clue about when the plane would take off.

articles.headline: Attacker Kills 4 Sunni Sheiks Who Aided U.S.
articles.snippet: A suicide bomber assassinated several Sunni Arab sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: A suicide bomber assassinated several Sunni Arab sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, June 26 — A suicide bomber on Monday assassinated four Sunni sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province. Witnesses said the bomber sneaked through security checkpoints, strode into a large Baghdad hotel and detonated an explosive belt just before lunchtime, killing 12 people including the sheiks.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Ali Adeeb

articles.headline: A Stock Filing Gone Awry for Bear Stearns
articles.snippet: A filing that would have allowed Bear Stearns to reduce its exposure to high-risk mortgages has been withdrawn.
articles.abstract: A filing that would have allowed Bear Stearns to reduce its exposure to high-risk mortgages has been withdrawn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in May, as Bear Stearns executives scrambled to meet redemption requests from clients in two troubled hedge funds, a money management company affiliated with the Wall Street firm filed its intention to sell $100 million worth of shares to public investors.

articles.headline: Mending Fences at World Bank
articles.snippet: Robert B. Zoellick, the new chief of the World Bank, will need to smooth ruffled feathers left by his predecessor Paul D. Wolfowitz.
articles.abstract: Robert B. Zoellick, the new chief of the World Bank, will need to smooth ruffled feathers left by his predecessor Paul D. Wolfowitz.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — For years, rumors of corruption surrounded an ambitious World Bank project for a system of reservoirs and water tunnels in the mountains of Lesotho in southern Africa. In 2002, the project director was convicted of graft and sent to jail.

articles.headline: Chinese Tires Are Ordered Recalled
articles.snippet: A U.S. tire importer disclosed that its Chinese manufacturer had stopped including a safety feature meant to prevent tread separation.
articles.abstract: A U.S. tire importer disclosed that its Chinese manufacturer had stopped including a safety feature meant to prevent tread separation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal officials have told a small New Jersey importer to recall 450,000 radial tires for pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and vans after the company disclosed that its Chinese manufacturer had stopped including a safety feature that prevented the tires from separating.
